title: Iluka flags $2b demerger of BHP iron ore royalties
text:
In addition to annual royalty payments, one-off capacity payments will be about $80 million payable as annual tonnages increase with the South Flank ramp up.

The royalty ensures Iluka 1.232 per cent of Australian dollar revenue from MAC and a one-off payment of $1 million per million tonne increase in annual capacity.

Iluka managing director Tom O’Leary said the company’s mineral sands business continued to be a global market leader in the production of zircon and high grade titanium feedstock.

“The business is producing solid cash flows in the current market environment and is well positioned for the future, with a pipeline of attractive growth projects,” he said.

The growth projects include a potential rare earth and zircon mining at Wimmera in Victoria’s Murray Basin and recovering mineral sands from a monazite-rich tailings stockpile at Eneabba in Western Australia.

Iluka said the completion of South Flank, which BHP says is 50 per cent complete and going to schedule, had the potential to materially increase MAC royalties cash flows.

“MAC earnings are derived from a high quality, long life asset. The MAC area is a high grade, low cost iron ore asset with a tier one operator in BHP,” Mr O’Leary said.

“Thanks to the South Flank development, it has significant growth in expected cash flows. In addition, further growth in the value of MAC is possible given the potential for the development by BHP of deposits within the area covered by the royalty agreement.”

Advertisement

Iluka said it would provide an update on the review when it announces full-year results in February. It has appointed Gresham Advisory Partners, Herbert Smith Freehills and Greenwoods as advisers.

The demerger was flagged by Street Talk earlier this month when it reported L1 was making the case that the royalty could be worth $2.1 billion to $2.4 billion on a net present value basis.

The L1 view is that the royalty should trade at a modest premium to non-precious metals peers because of the size and quality of the underlying iron ore operations.

The royalty could be distributed to Iluka investors via an in-specie distribution, similar to the way Wesfarmers demerged Coles last year or when BHP Billiton spun off South32 in 2015.
description: Mineral sands miner considering spin off with steep increase in earnings from new BHP's South Flank mine on the horizon.
